articles.headline: Call to Curb Speculators in Energy
articles.snippet: The top commodity market regulator said that the U.S. should consider limiting some energy futures trading.
articles.abstract: The top commodity market regulator said that the U.S. should consider limiting some energy futures trading.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The country’s top regulator of commodity markets said Tuesday that the government should “seriously consider” strict limits on the trades of purely financial investors in the futures markets for oil, natural gas and other energy products.

articles.headline: Supplements for Athletes Draw Alert From F.D.A.
articles.snippet: Consumers were told not to use body-building products that are sold as supplements but may contain steroids.
articles.abstract: Consumers were told not to use body-building products that are sold as supplements but may contain steroids.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal regulators warned consumers on Tuesday not to use body-building products that are sold as nutritional supplements but may contain steroids or steroidlike substances, citing reports of acute liver injury and kidney failure.
articles.byline: By Natasha Singer and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Aeroflot Sheds Its Soviet Legacy and Turns to a Western Fleet
articles.snippet: The Russian airline, which is reinventing itself as a business carrier, will soon be mostly using planes made by Airbus and Boeing.
articles.abstract: The Russian airline, which is reinventing itself as a business carrier, will soon be mostly using planes made by Airbus and Boeing.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  Aeroflot’s symbol is still the winged hammer and sickle, but otherwise, the former communist carrier has mostly shrugged off its Soviet past. The strongest evidence yet: by the end of the year, it will fly a fleet nearly entirely made in the U.S.A. and Western Europe.

articles.headline: Health Care Reform and the Unpopular T-Word
articles.snippet: Taxing health care may be the surest way to slow its growth, but members of Congress are not so eager.
articles.abstract: Taxing health care may be the surest way to slow its growth, but members of Congress are not so eager.

articles.headline: How Firms Wooed a U.S. Agency With Billions to Invest
articles.snippet: Charles E. F. Millard, head of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, is under investigation for inappropriate contacts with Wall Street firms seeking to obtain lucrative contracts.
articles.abstract: Charles E. F. Millard, head of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, is under investigation for inappropriate contacts with Wall Street firms seeking to obtain lucrative contracts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As a New York money manager and investment banker at four Wall Street firms, Charles E. F. Millard never reached superstar status. But he was treated like one when he arrived in Washington in May 2007, to run the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, the federal agency that oversees $50 billion in retirement funds.

articles.headline: A Rorschach Cheat Sheet on Wikipedia?
articles.snippet: Psychologists and Wikipedia users are at loggerheads over whether images used for Hermann Rorschach’s inkblot test should be available online.
articles.abstract: Psychologists and Wikipedia users are at loggerheads over whether images used for Hermann Rorschach’s inkblot test should be available online.
articles.lead_paragraph: There are tests that have right answers, which are returned with a number on top in a red circle, and there are tests with open-ended questions, which provide insight into the test taker’s mind.

articles.headline: Even Google Is Blocked With Apps for iPhone
articles.snippet: There is tension between the companies because Apple sometimes rejects Google’s applications for the App Store.
articles.abstract: There is tension between the companies because Apple sometimes rejects Google’s applications for the App Store.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google might power the world’s most popular search engine, but its clout goes only so far. When it comes to getting one of its applications onto the iPhone, it seems Google has to wait in line for Apple’s approval like everyone else  and face the risk of rejection.

articles.headline: Obama Faces Court Test Over Detainee
articles.snippet: The case of a young detainee captured in Afghanistan has turned into a showdown between the courts and the executive branch.
articles.abstract: The case of a young detainee captured in Afghanistan has turned into a showdown between the courts and the executive branch.
articles.lead_paragraph: The fate of one of the youngest detainees at the Guantánamo Bay prison is emerging as a major test of whether the courts or the president has the final authority over when prisoners there are released.

articles.headline: Microsoft and Yahoo Are Linked Up. Now What?
articles.snippet: Microsoft and Yahoo announced that they had agreed to collaborate on Internet search and advertising in a bid to challenge Google.
articles.abstract: Microsoft and Yahoo announced that they had agreed to collaborate on Internet search and advertising in a bid to challenge Google.
articles.lead_paragraph: The bumpy, marathon mating dance between Microsoft and Yahoo finally concluded on Wednesday, when the two companies announced a partnership in Internet search and advertising to take on the industry powerhouse Google.
